author: CookieSetton

description.text:
Hand cranked gumball machine. Video:http://youtu.be/Wts8OPt1Hdw
See instructions tab.

Materials:
Print (1) of each STL file. Print base with support material. My settings were .4 nozzle, .4 infill, layer height .2.
(1) piece of plexiglass for the window 5 3/4" x 3 5/8"
(1) flexible vinyl fabric 1 1/8" x 6"
brass rods:
(1) 1 1/2" long x 1/4"
(1) 3 1/2" long x 1/4"
(1) 3" long x 1/4"
(1) 1 1/2" long x 1/8"
(3) 1/4" wheel collars
(2) 1/8" wheel collars
(1) wood base 11x7x3/4"
gumballs Glue the receiver to the base; lining up the right hand side. I used acetone and ABS mixture. Glue the vinyl to the slide triangle and the inside left wall of the base. See pictures. Glue brass rods to the hubs (place the long rod thru the hubstand first! I drilled the handle and the hubstand with a 19/64" drill bit to make them spin easily. Add wheel collars and line everything up before screwing to the wood base. Add gumballs and top. I put rubber feet on the wood base.
So far the abs glue is working fine. If the hubs break loose, then the brass rods may need to be pinned to the hubs.
Hope your kids/grandkids enjoy this as much as mine do!

comments.text: To work with an STL in Rhino I believe you've going to have to convert the part using the "MeshToNurbs" command.  Note that it's probably still going to be a real pain to work with.
comments.author: cpdude

comments.text: STL files have no information about the structure of the object - it's just the shape of the skin. That's enough for 3D printing, and it's a format that every modeling program can generate, which is why it's as the common format all over Thingiverse. But it's nearly impossible to edit STLs. It's like editing a PDF generated from an MS Word document. About all you can do with an STL is scale or crop it.
comments.author: cpdude

title: Cabinet Lock for Child Safety
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I've designed it for my kitchen under counter cabinets.

I have ten months old child who is curious about inside of cabinets. Children safety products on the market are hard to use. They are not practical especially for using on the under counter cabinets.

So I decided to build up my own safety locks.
I used 1 mm thick acrylic double sided adhesive tapes to mount pieces to cabinet and counter.

Disclaimer: Cohesive resistance may change according to product. I used 4kg/cm2 tape and it worked for my case. I let my children to force cabinet doors to open while I was ensuring its safety but they worked well. These type adhesive are really powerful but as never leave your children unattended.

You may buy me a beer;

title: Spring Loaded Caliper for filament thickness measurement (For bigger calipers)

description.text:
This is a remix of the "Spring Loaded Caliper" project by ianjohnson.
When I printed the project parts, I noticed that my caliper legs didn't fit in there, since the caliper leg slots where designed for thinner calipers.
The files contained on this thing are the 2 parts from Ian's "CaliperRollerv2.stl", but with the slots increased by 4mm to fit my caliper, and split into 2 different files instead of just 1.

In case anyone wonders, this is the caliper I'm using: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000GSLKIW/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

This is the logo for the Galactic Republic from Star Wars (1-3). I've included 4 models:

  • Logo Inverted
  • Logo with background

This is just one logo of my Star Wars logo collection. Here are the links for the others:

  • Rebel Logo
  • Galactic Empire
  • Galactic Republic
  • Mandalorian (Bounty Hunter)

description.text:
A simple rack for holding darts. Print how many you need, connect them, and then hang on the wall however you want. I'm going to drill a hole in mine and hang them with a nail.

I included the sketchup file in case you wanted to modify it to suit your needs.

Printer:

ANET A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.32

Infill:

15 Honeycomb

Notes:

I've used wood filament and have a little stringing on my, but nothing a little sandpaper won't fix. Really, you can use whatever slicing parameters you want I would think.

title: Arduino Controlled Servo Robot

description.text: A fun little open source Arduino powered robot to play around with.

For full instructions on how to assemble, program and expand please visit:
http://www.instructables.com/id/How_to_Make_an_Arduino_Controlled_Servo_Robot_SER/ (shameless plug) If you don't have access to a laser cutter full kits, with everything you need to get up and running, are available at:
http://store.oomlout.com/arduino-controlled-servo-robot-serb--kit1.html Or if you have access to a laser cutter and would like to buy all the hardware, motors and Arduino to make it run, that is also an option:
http://store.oomlout.com/hardware.html

author: oomlout

description.text:
This is a head of a small project I started years ago. The entire bot is about 3 inches long (see image), it's programmable and moves via muscle wire. I'm looking at purchasing the Cupcake to finish this project, but I really need to understand the resolution of the printer before I spend the money. So, I'm looking for someone who has a cupcake that will print the head for me to review the detail level resolution.
-Bob

comments.text: Bob,  out of curiosity I took a stab at it, using the methodology I described.  The attached images are the result.  There is a 6in architectural scale in one of the pictures.  I didn't hollow out the inside, because that would have been quite a bit of work.
comments.author: Skimbal

comments.text: From what I can see, its printable.  But not in its current form, or at the current scale.  To print it I would double the scale and cut it in half down the axis of symmetry (the middle of the head).
comments.author: Skimbal

This is a customizable prism map of the contiguous United States. Values are represented by the extruded height of each state. (An extruded polygon is a prism.) The default dataset depicts population density: 2010 census total population counts normalized by state area in square kilometers. Click Open in Customizer to plug in your own data for each state and to adjust the model dimensions. Create your own customizable prism map models from shapefiles without ease using prismap. Pull requests and bug reports are welcome.
Printed with raft (still attached in some photos), 10% infill, 2 shells, and 0.15mm layer height. Printed version customized with floor disabled and slightly smaller dimensions than default.

My little sister wanted some hemispherical LED diffusers for some 5mm LEDs. Here you go!

Use a translucent filament, and reduce the infill as low as you want. She used a flat top LED, and put them around her mirror in her bedroom.

Photos are by my father, Tom Wolf.

comments.text: Build Notes: I tried PLA and PETG, and PETG was noticeably brighter. Used 0.8mm shell thickness with 0% infill. I used a 15/64 inch drill bit to clear the socket on the sphere and drill out the top of the socket. This allows the 5mm flattop LED to extend past the end of the socket. ordered LEDs from Amazon (https://goo.gl/5CuZ7M). The plunger will have to be cleaned up with emery cloth to fit / get a good friction fit. If that is not sufficient, try reprinting the plunger with a 1% scaled smaller on x / y. With a 1k resistor, they run well in parallel on 5v.

This is my first original model I've printed. Made in Rhino3d mac.

These are models for N-gauge model railway shipping containers in 2 of the most common formats 20 foot and 40 foot.
They print at lo-res in about 30 mins and use about 2.5meters of PLA.

Designed in OpenScad (files provided)

It was relatively simple as it is all a bunch of cubes - perfect for OpenScad.

The original sizes were found on the internet, then scaled by 160:1 to arrive at the right size for N-scale model trains.

plate_height = 10
text_height = 5
plate_width = 65
font_size = 20
text_content = Treasure

This is an extremely cheap laser diffraction grating which can be used, along with an ordinary laser pointer, to conduct the double-slit experiment and demonstrate the wave/particle duality of light. See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Double-slit_experiment for further details on this experiment.

Two STL files are included, DiffGrating50 and DiffGrating25. DiffGrating50 is much easier to print, but does not work quite as well.   
To print, set your layer height to .25mm and make your extrusion width 0.4mm. Make sure that your slicer is not producing a fatter extrusion on the first layer, otherwise you'll get a solid thin film, not a set of slits.

comments.text: Um... Ya...As a physicst and engineer, this is not a double split. This is the first layer of a raft or support on a frame. You are manually creating the slits. This has absolutely nothing to do with the probability exparament, which only has one adjustable slit. Nice try, but no. If I did this in class and called it a double split, I would get laughed at and failed by the professor. It's time you open a science book and do it properly. What you gave here is a "slit shade" something you would use in film lighting. But even then, it's not usable. And it's so crazy inaccurate that even if it was a double split, it wouldn't work properly and the results would be noisy. You would not be able to distinguish what was a probability line and what was a piece of dust or a shadow from inconsistent lines. (remember there are NOT precision machines and won't be for a long time.)
comments.author: DevWolf

comments.text: I just had the exact same idea a couple hours ago! Pretty crazy!
comments.author: Alpha_Pi_Rho

comments.text: Way cool! I whipped this design up earlier in the year for a friend who teaches middle school who needed a cool science demo. I'm sure it can be improved in many ways. I need to get to work and design a gizmo that holds two of these gratings at different angles.

title: 9 Layer Raspberry TFT Screen Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is an adaptation of the 9 layer case I previously used for Raspberry Pi 3B. I used the supplied nylon screws by removing 3 of the original layers. I removed the bottom layer and the 2 top layers to fit this case with a TFT 3.5 screen (a generic Waveshare screen like the following:

http://www.waveshare.com/wiki/3.5inch_RPi_LCD_(A). I got my generic screen on Aliexpress for just about $11 USD.

This is the screen I bought. Shipping was so SLOW! Maybe consider finding a different seller.
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Free-Shipping-2014-New-Arrival-1Pcs-3-2-Inch-LCD-Touch-Screen-Display-Monitor-Module-For/32470294229.html?spm=2114.13010608.0.0.oJxHNZ

I used the Waveshare drivers with the screen and had no issues in building an Octoprint rig with the Touch UI. Octoprint is great if you want to move away from the constant need of having to transport your SD card to your printer each time you want to print.

There are 3 custom layers A, B, and C. A goes above the screen. B goes around the screen. C goes underneath the screen.

If you have the same case from EEEKit, you're in luck and can easily modify it to add a 3.5 TFT display.

Enjoy!

Printer:

Anet_A6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1 Layer height .3 nozzle

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I ended up using 5 top layers on layer "A" to make sure I got a nice finish on the top of the case.

description.text:
This allows you to use an external battery/power supply with your Sony digital camera. Designed to replace the NP-BN1 battery pack.

1) Print
2) Glue two strips of copper for + / - terminals
3) Solder wires, and run down the grooves
4) Connect to battery/PSU
5) Insert into camera. There should be a little flap on the camera for the wires to poke out.

title: Seek CompactPro Thermal Imager Mount for iPhone 7 Plus

description.text:
Recently I purchased a Seek CompactPro (Thermal Imager) and wasn't comfortable with the way the Camera mounted on the Lightning port. Firstly, the device is costly and I didn't want it to fall out or break off. Secondly the mounting felt awkward during use.

This is a simple mount the encompasses the Seek CompactPro and snaps on the back of my iPhone 7 Plus with Tech 21 case. Because I know most people aren't going to have my phone/case combo I included the Rhino File.

Lightning Adapter I used
3mm Plastic Screws I used

** I assume this will work for all of their versions (Compact & CompactXR) including the micro USB, however I have no way of confirming it.

comments.text: Awesome, I've been wanting something like this!  I have the XR, and the PRO!..   Coolest things EVER!!!   Hey wanna know a couple secrets I've discovered???   Go into the app, go to "about" and hit "image processing software" 5 times...  Cool huh? (Easter EGG)  I about crapped my pants when I discovered that!  And, I haven't seen anything online referencing it, SO, I'm declaring right here and now, to the internet. "I discovered this!!! lol,  and here's another for ya, using the pro, with any palette up, click on your tools, then choose the one that looks like 2 circles on a vertical line...  OK, now with that, click on the settings gear, then click the right side of the screen to go back to viewing... BAM, you're now in a new palette, well its actually an older one that's been disabled from way back when called "cool"
comments.author: JU571N

comments.text: Nice job discovering those Easter Eggs, I will have to check them out! In regards to your iPhone, I only made it for the plus. If you are new to Rhino, this is the perfect project to start learning! Lynda is a great place to start: https://www.lynda.com/Rhino-tutorials/Rhino-5-Essential-Training/133324-2.html

description.text:
A stand for my old school lego x-wing. I made it to look like the surface of the death star. I included the .f3d file if you want to edit it in fusion 360.

I assembled it all with some CA glue (Super glue). You have the freedom to decide in what orientation you want to assemble it.

You can also decide to point the front of the X-Wing downwards or upwards when attaching the Lego model to the stand.

The print shown in the pictures was printed at 110% scale, i designed it a bit small for my liking.
Painted with warhammer type acrylic paint.

title: NSTT Extruder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is the NSTT Extruder. (Revision 2 now available)

I've designed this extruder in December 2016 and after some heavy testing and redesigning I decided to share it.

NSTT stands for "Not So Tiny Titan" and is an E3D Titan inspired printable extruder. Despite the name it is a pretty compact geared extruder when compared with other geared extruders.

It has the same 3:1 gear ratio as the E3D Titan.

It incorporates parts from my initial MK8 extruder like the spring, the hobbed gear and the 623z bearing.

To built this is necessary:
-4x M3x10 screws and nuts
-1x M5x40 screw (Hexagonal head) a M5 nut and an M5 nylon lock nut
-5x M3x25 M3 screw and nut
-1x M4x20 screw (internal hex head) and nut
-2x
option 1-625ZZ bearings (needs 1xM5 washer)
option 2-688ZZ or F688ZZ bearings (no need for washers)
-1x 623z bearing and a M3 washer
-1x MK8 hobbed gear
-1x MK8 tension spring
-1x extra 625z if using idler+body B

Update (revision 2)

16-07-2017
Revision 2 of the extruder is now available. Here are the changes

  • New extruder lit that will offer support to stress caused by the idler spring tension that causes cracking on the top of the body near the outer bearing.
  • New assembly option for the idler main shaft. This allows for the using of the stepper shaft has the idler shaft has the initial version of the extruder.
  • New filament coupler design to prevent miss-alignments.
  • Included the stepper motor adapter sketchup file so you can modify/adapt the support to any given stepper or support on your printer.

Update (revision 1)

17-04-2017

  • New body that features a side window to allow tightening/cleaning of the hobbed MK8 gear without the need to disassemble the extruder.
  • Added a teflon tube insert/holder on the input side of the feeding system.
  • Supressed the need for 625ZZ bearings on the filament idler (lighter)
  • Redesigned gears. Easier to print and fit/match on assembly.
  • New option for bearing usage on the M5 long screw that allows better performance/less trouble. 688ZZ or F688ZZ can be used by using the available spacers. This also eliminates the need of using washers in the main axis (washers are hard to center/align). New stepper mount plate to accommodate new gears

Update

09-02-2017

  • added filament guide on the extruder body (filament input side). Although the MK8 hobbed gear keeps the filament in the right track the filament can skip from the 623zz bearing and get stuck outside the gear causing the print to fail. The new filament guide prevents this.

Assembly

Instructional video here:
New Revision 2 - https://youtu.be/ww7HrSxefLU
Original version (outdated) - https://youtu.be/Cpo0SOepOIE (outdated)

  1. Insert the small gear in the stepper shaft. It will self lock.
  2. Put the M3 nuts in the motor mount base and screw the motor mount to the stepper (M3x10).
  3. Pick up the M5x40 screw and insert in this order:

    For the 625 bearings (option 1)

    • Big gear
    • M5 washer
    • 625 bearing
    • 625 spacer A
    • MK8 hobbed gear

    For the 688 bearings (option 2)

    • Big gear
    • 688 spacer A
    • 688 bearing
    • MK8 hobbed gear

    Mark were the side screw is hits the M5 screw remove it all and use a tool file to make a dent in the M5 screw. Reassemble all and tight the MK8 hobbed screw in place.

  4. Connect the two printed gears and insert the extruder body, fitting the bearing in the main body slot. Some adjustments to the position of the small printed gear in the stepper shaft may be required to allow correct alignment. Screw the extruder body to the base (M3x25).
  5. Assemble the filament idler. If using body+idler option B insert the 625 bearing in the idler. Insert the M3 nut on the back of the idler. Insert an M3 washer then the 623 bearing (washer is on the nut size and the bearing is on the side of the screw head) and screw the bearing ans washer in place (M3x10).
  6. Screw the M4 nut on the M4 screw and place the MK8 tension spring in the M4 screw. Place it as the pictures shows (back side of idler)
  7. Fit the idler in the stepper shaft.
  8. Place the filament guide in place.
  9. Screw the extruder lit in place. Insert the rest of the shaft parts by this order:

    For the 625 bearings (option 1)

    • 625 spacer B
    • 625 bearing
    • M5 nut

    For the 688 bearings (option 2)

    • 688 bearing
    • 688 spacer B
    • M5 nut
  10. Tight all with the M5 nut (use your fingers). You want it to tight it very mildly so it wont load the bearings too much. Insert the M5 nylon lock nut on top of this.

Note: The MK8 hobbed gear has very shallow teeth and not very sharp to avoid deforming the filament. In my case I have to apply a considerate amount of force to the tension sprint to avoid filament slip. I unscrew the M4 nut half way (see main picture).

The rest is up to you. Either use the E3D in direct feed mode or print the adapter (two halfs) to install the pneumatic coupler to use it has a bowden extruder.

In Marlin configure the E steps/mm to about 440. Test it and adjust.

Enjoy your new geared extruder. The printing quality on this is worth it!!!

Printer:

P3Steel

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

50%

author: colgarb

description.text:
My Greenfield rear triangle mounted kickstand came with a rubber foot that tore through within a month or two. Terrible for touring because the sharp metal end pokes through on soft ground easily, sinks in, & your bike falls over.

I imagine this would work for any Greenfield kickstand for which the foot looks like the images provided. I think this includes:

  • https://www.amazon.com/Greenfield-Kickstand-Brushed-Aluminum-Finish/dp/B000AOA452/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1486422848&sr=8-1&keywords=greenfield+kickstand
  • https://www.amazon.com/Greenfield-KS2-305B-305mm-Kickstand-Frames/dp/B001GSKVO0/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1486422848&sr=8-2&keywords=greenfield+kickstand
  • https://www.amazon.com/Greenfield-SKS2-305B-Stablizer-Stay-Mount-aluminum/dp/B002FVYTLI/ref=sr_1_3?ie=UTF8&qid=1486422848&sr=8-3&keywords=greenfield+kickstand This is the one I own.

This (https://www.amazon.com/Greenfield-KSRF-Kickstand-Foot-Black/dp/B00IBFJIYA/ref=sr_1_6?ie=UTF8&qid=1486422848&sr=8-6&keywords=greenfield+kickstand) is the original foot. Terrible design.

What I wanted was something more durable, & provided a larger platform on the ground so the bike wouldn't sink, especially on soft ground. The foot would be replaceable if it ever wore out. See the Assembly section.

My bikes live indoors, so I don't want them to scratch hardwood with the metal kickstands.

High resolution scan of old foot.

I scanned my old foot, scaled it, & copied the dimensions over.

I approximated some other dimensions.

Part of the inspiration came from a kickstand my father made me for my first rear bike, shown below. It was a piece of plastic for/from a mold, epoxied in place. Very hard wearing plastic too, with a large platform. Sadly I didn't like the placement of this kind of kickstand.

• compatible kickstand
  • epoxy/glue
  • old tire

The 3D printed piece should be large enough to fit over the metal end. Apply a lot of epoxy &/or glue to secure the piece to the kickstand.

Cut a section out of an old tire (maybe around a 700 x 28 size) & wrap it around the swept section at the bottom. Glue this on.

6 Feb 17: still working on this. The swept feature is not working like I want it to. Project on hold unless someone can help or I stop being lazy &/or get interested in this thing again. I even tried to cut off the excess. It's supposed to be symmetric about an obvious plane.

I based this off of the design by keraynopoylos' "Cable bundle holder for Robo3D printer" which is at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:162100 This accomplishes the same thing. When you remove the cover from the Robo3D printer the zip tie that holds the cable bundle above the extruder is removed and thus the cable bundle is now loose and has no support. This mounts to the size of the X carriage motor (same side as the cable bundle) and is secured using an M3 bolt, flat washer and lock nut. I built this one instead of using keraynopoylos' holder because of a few reasons. 1) the hole for the cable bundle has been widened; 2) the base of this bundle is thicker and thus has less warping due to strain from the cable bundle; and 3) I've widened the hole that the M3 bolt will go into giving it a little more clearance. v2 of this cable holder has a longer cable holder section to try to keep the cable vertical. Designed using Tinkercad. Design is at https://tinkercad.com/things/496dpPRuGsZ

description.text:
Phone dock for the Pixel XL. Designed for the standard USB-C cord that comes in the box.

Pieces slot together, but CA glue is recommended to keep it together.

Are you getting bits of filament all over the place while you clean up your 3d printed parts? Not any more!

This is a drawer, more or less, that slides out from under a desk or table to allow easy access to a plastic shopping bag that will catch all of your plastic scraps. I wanted to make sure that I wasn't leaving any filament scraps where my dogs would eat them.

Printed on an SeeMeCNC Orion
.3 Layer height but it doesn't matter too much. I went for speed, not beauty.
Use supports on the Arms and Sliders.
Use a raft when printing rails.
There are full plate files as well as individual parts for printing what you need.
My Orion has a reliable print area of 150mm by 240mm. Some of the plates exceeded that area but it didn't seem to mind too much.

As for the movement of the sliders against the rails, I used petroleum jelly to lubricate them. It's quite possible that there are many things one could use. Hell if your desperate enough, whip out the KY. LOL!

To hold the bag in place the best, especially when there isn't much weight in it, I use a rubber ban wrapped around the part where the arms attache to the sliders.

It all gets held together with #6 screws and nuts.

This was laser cut from 0.8mm cardboard. The svg contains 7 snowflakes on a 60x30cm carton board.  
If you have cardboard with another thickness there is an example in the second layer of the svg. Change the width of the yellow blocks and cut it from the snowflake shapes (path > difference in Inkscape). Don't correct for cutting loss, in that way the parts can rotate a little. The material needs to be a bit flexible, otherwise you can't assemble the outer ring.

description.text: This a simple mount for the Arduino uno board, simply slide the board in and use a #4 pan head screw to hold it in place, I use this mount to mount the board in high vibration machines and it holds up great
This is an item designed to test the limits of a 3D printer. This part would be impossible to make with other manufacturing processes, which is why it is special to the 3D printing world.

Shunting viaduct HO scale

This is a H0 scale (1:87) shunting viaduct.
It is a curved ramp that goes down from 80 mm in height to 7 mm in a total track length of approx 100 cm.
The curved part has a radius of 415 mm and is designed for use with the Fleishmann curved rails with that radius (415 mm).
It comes in 7 parts that are all under 180 mm long and max 125 mm wide, so it can be printed on a wide range of 3D printers.
Except for part 5, all parts can be printed without support material.
The design has been created for a layer height of 0.18 mm.
It can best be printed using a 0.3 mm or 0.4 mm nozzle diameter.

For the curved parts (part 4+5+6) a sidewalk can be optionally printed alongside the track. (See all 6 "sidewalk" STL files).

To hide the seam between parts 1-2 and 2-3 extra pillars can be optionally printed that can be glued on the outside (wall) of the viaduct. (See all 4 "pillar" STL files).

The viaduct contains the relief of more than 17000 bricks on its walls. This relief makes it easy to "wash in" the mortar of the brick walls with some light paint (grey) color, before painting the brick (dark red) with a roller or sponge.

For me printing times per part varied from 8 - 16 hours.
It took approximately 2 kg of filament to print all parts.

I have included a PDF drawing showing the most important sizes of the viaduct in mm.

Happy printing!

Huib Schippers (Tinkerman)

comments.text: what software package did you use to model the bricks?
comments.author: elwoodblues

comments.text: At first I tried to model the bricks using a bump map in Blender, but in order to make that work the mesh had to consist out of millions of polygons, so I ended up modelling a strip of interlocking bricks (vertically) that I copied along the outer contour of the walls (copy along spline) for a couple of hundred times and finally cutting off the part of those brick-strips that was too high, using boolean operations. In the end I fused everything together using boolean union operations.... Everything took a lot of (waiting) time for these operations to complete,, but now the model has a minimal number of polygons without the loss of geometry / detail.

description.text:
Standing support for Asus RT-AC88U.
The 3 sticks are optional and the support is stable without them.

Update:
you can print the link bar instead of using sticks if you feel like it's necessary.

You will need to drill holes to attach the router. The height of the support is just right to still access the usb port and the wifi/led switches.

Will work for other routers too.

comments.text: Since ASUS didn't provide a stand for this router and I wanted one, I do appreciate that someone made this design and shared it - and I made it work. But I have some suggestions.The main side pieces need to be like 3/4" taller right where you drill the holes. Where the holes are drilled in the pics, they're SO close to the top that they could crack out when drilling, or break later. I was afraid of that, so I drilled my holes 1-2 mm lower. But the router sits lower, so it barely leaves room for the USB port door at the bottom to open and for you to connect a USB cable. Making the vertical pieces a bit taller at the top hurts nothing and would solve that. I also wonder why if the design can have holes left in them for those wooden dowels, why can't the design include holes near the top so I wouldn't need to drill there at all? Then, I didn't want to hunt for the dowels, but I did want cross support. So I had that piece printed also. Only after I received them all did I see that the cross piece was meant to go across the bottom of the stand and under it. That makes no sense, because the stand wobbles with part of the u-shaped piece being under it. Even with the weight of the router on it, just the teeniest nudge makes it rock back. I couldn't stand that. So I moved the cross piece from the bottom to the back. I considered epoxying it there. But that could be messy. . .

description.text:
I told you that I continued to work to improve my model of spinner, it is done with my first functional model, and it goes beyond my hope, still lack a little power but it will take you the head when You will start to spin this stuff! I have made a modification to the outer diameter of the model, so it is smaller. Now the thickness is 6 mm against 5 mm on the proto it brings a better resistance to the spiral spring. I used a system of ball brake (and it is damn effective), 2 in total of a diameter between 1.8mm and 2mm recovered in a ball bearing cut to the dremell. The balls must move freely in their housings. And the adjustment is done with the help of a small adjust as shown in the picture. I already have my next model in the head, go hop! I'm back!

description.text:
Print one of everything with the exception of the Spring catch - you will need two of them.

I suggest printing the bottom of the casing with support, though its not mandatory.

You will need a spring that fits between the two catches, I personally grabbed one from the local ACE hardware. You don't want the spring to be too hard to pull apart so go for an easier spring rather than power. The comb really doesn't need much to extend it as its light.

On my printer the amount of sanding needed to make everything slide nicely was basically zero. Your machine may vary.

I printed mine in PETG

NB: Ok this should go without saying but this is intended as a novelty. Don't go doing anything stupid like modifying it to have a real blade. OTF switchblades are illegal in several states. Additionally be aware that schools etc have pretty much a zero tolerance policy for anything even remotely looking like a weapon. Be smart.

This design uses anti warp panels. Should print in ABS with very little warping. Let me know how it works for you.  
I added wall mount versions.
I like to print this with a .50 nozzle using .3mm layer height. I use Hair spray at 95c on an Makergear M2 printer.

comments.text: I read about anti warp corrugation someplace on the internet someplace but could not find any useful info or parts so I built panels to test it out. I theorized that the long ABS threads were shrinking at different rates due to the temperature differences as the print progresses and warping my ABS parts. These walls avoid long threads, absorb some tension and help with warping a lot. I can build boxed the full size of my build plate with very little warping. There is lots to testing to do still. I was hoping to get some people to print some large parts and report back their experience.

title: Single Din Pocket Plus Custom Files

description.text:
I've uploaded a simple pocket design in addition to what you see pictured. This is without the slots for the voltmeter and the switch. I've also attached the Fusion 360 file for you to modify if you need. I'm not sure what holes this will fit, but it fits in my 2000 Tacoma, and my understanding is that the holes are relatively universal.

If you are curious about what the rest of my project was read further down.

Most important is to not print this in PLA. PLA has a glass temp that is too low for use inside of vehicles. I chose to use PETG as it prints easily and has a high enough glass temp. ABS would also work well. Pick your material carefully.

I've had this in mind for a project for a while and couldn't find anything that fit my needs. I wanted two LCD Voltmeters for the two batteries I have in my truck. This also required a "Double Pole Single Throw" switch to have the voltmeters run to each batter seperately, yet only need one switch to turn on both.

The voltemeters I used: https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B00BZPH6KQ/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1
The switch I used: https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B00004WLK9/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Printer:

Qidi Tech 1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Most important is to not print this in PLA. PLA has a glass temp that is too low for use inside of vehicles. I chose to use PETG as it prints easily and has a high enough glass temp. ABS would also work well. Pick your material carefully.

I ran this with 20% support, last 3 layers of support was 40%.

I printed face up (pretty side ends last) with 6 layers on top to insure complete fill on final layers.

The Single Din with only the pocket does not need support and should print fine without it.

2 print runs are needed to make the full rack. 1 half of the rack and 1 locking pin are printed in each print run. They are interlocking so will require glue / bonding together. I made the interlocking parts with a bit of wiggle room for the bots that do not print to tight specs so should hold reasonably tight. I have not printed this later revision of the rack because i already have 2 printed up and each after each print i discoverd tiny problems that i needed to change. I have one printed in abs and one in pla. my preference would be pla here but as its used outside and sometimes in damp / dew areas then abs would prob be better but its all up to the print master and their preferences.

title: Prusa I3 Y Bushing Bearing holder - strong

description.text:
This is a bearing holder I created. It is designed with the mounting holes 28mm center to center, which seems to be standard on the aluminum plates I have bought from China.

It is strong, you will need to pry it open a bit to insert the bearing. Each end has an internal rib/hump that will keep the bearing center between the ribs. I have designed it so you can use zip ties, as well, although in my use, they have not been necessary. If you do use zip ties, they must be of the smaller variety, large zip ties will not fit. I only used the zip tie in the picture, not in real life as the holder holds the bearing so tight that I do not feel zip ties are necessary.

STL and original Sketchup 2017 files included. Use as you like, freely, sell, share whatever, remix if you like.

Prusa Steel

description.text:
Panzer vor!

Big thanks to user mmorao
(http://www.thingiverse.com/mmorao/about) he provided me with some fantastic reference books that made modeling these 100 times easier.

A collection of 1:100 panzer 4 models

currently contains
Panzer Ausf A
Panzer Ausf B/C
Panzer Ausf D
Panzer Ausf E
Panzer Ausf F1 (+schurzen turret and hull)
Panzer Ausf F2
Panzer Ausf G
Panzer Ausf H
Panzer Ausf J
Dicker Max

All hulls and turrets are made from scratch.

I know I should do so before posting but I haven't test print these yet. Because of the nature of my printer it would probably delay posting this by a month if i did. I can confirm that the tacks do fit after printing however.

Two new features in this pack!!! first i was asked to upload as parasolid, this should make remix making easier for those who wish to do so. Second, hulls and tracks are now separated. I don't know how I feel about this ask me in a month : ).

like before I included special command hatch versions of the turrets with open commander hatches. These should be reserved for higher scale prints. I don't think they will print properly at 1:100 but your welcome to try

Please join my group http://www.thingiverse.com/groups/the-world-at-war/topics

title: Samsung SmartThings Motion Sensor Magnetic Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I previously printed some "ball & socket" type mounts for my SmartThings motion sensors around my house but after a few weeks they loosened up and would not hold the sensor in position. I want a simple low profile mount that easily allows me to swivel and remove the sensors to change batteries, so I didn't want anything that required tools. These are a fixed downward angle so I have one t around 78 degrees and another at about 72 degrees that I just eyeballed for position. I may add another at a lower angle yet for those that want it to point down a bit further yet. They can rotate 360 degrees around the base.

I used a double sided adhesive foam tape to mount the base to the ceiling and the other half fits onto the sensor using the keyhole mount on the back, with just enough play to level out the sensor. I imagine it could be used with other keyhole based products as well, if they are light enough.

Each mount uses two 12x3mm magnets that I got very cheap from the local big box.

Pumps water or slurries using garden hose pressure. The critical parameters for pumping efficiency and hose/pipe connections are parametrisable. Single piece, no moving parts. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QxKf6R1Fu88 I designed this thing because I unexpectedly needed to empty a pool filter. The filter is basically a large sphere filled with sand and water and a small hole on top. A normal pump would get killed by the sand and emptying it by hand is no fun.

The default design fits into a 10x10x10cm print envelope. Print as is, no support material needed. Almost solid infill and many shells and solid layers to make it as waterproof as possible. It will work with a small amount of leakage though. ABS is the recommended material, because then the whole thing can be painted with ABS+Acetone paste for better waterproofing. The default settings are to match a standard 40mm PVC pressure pipe, which, for some reason, has an inner diameter of 43mm. It requires a 1 inch thread garden hose adapter, commonly found with spray nozzles. See pictures. The dimensions in the diagram above correspond to some of the parameters in the OpenScad file. These are the critical parameters for pump efficiency.

The nozzle turns the garden hose pressure into high speed flow. The high speed water flow after the nozzle generates a vacuum which sucks in liquid. The nozzle offset from the throat should be selected to ensure that the flow diverges to throat diameter just inside the throat. Inside the throat, the liquid mixes with the high speed water and is accelerated by it. The longer the throat is, the better the impulse transfer, but a long throat also increases friction losses. The mixed flow expands after the throat. This slows the flow, but increases pressure. The ratio of throat area to pipe area is the factor that determines outlet pressure. By changing this ratio it is possible to select between high flow / low pressure or low flow / high pressure. Warning: The combination of high pressure and printed plastic can be more interesting than expected. To avoid injury, please always submerge pump before turning on the garden hose.

title: LED Diffuser for High Resolution 1701-D Warpcore

description.text:
These diffusers turn the light from the diffused LEDs into an even 345degree column of light. This is done by printing a column of fanned out light pipes that radiate from the LED.

Continue reading below the videos!

Videos: They are all very short.
Warpcore running at warp factor 2

Warpcore Standard from Novel Mutations on Vimeo.

Warpcore running in rainbow mode at warp factor 2

Warpcore Rainbow from Novel Mutations on Vimeo.

Warpcore mid breach. It starts at warp 1 and ramps up to warp 9 while the reaction chamber followed by the rest turn from blue to red before it slows down to warp 0 and repeats. Unfortunately I missed the beginning so the video is really short and only shows from about warp 7 onwards.

Warpcore Breach from Novel Mutations on Vimeo.

There are two other modes where it fades the the entire thing through the entire color spectrum that I did not make videos of.
I want to add the ability to make it a vu meter as well.

This is designed to work with my High Resolution Warpcore Remix of ThePlanetMikes Warpcore. It will NOT fit the original.

This design uses WS2801 NON-INSULATED Diffused Pixels that have been separated, wrapped in Kapton tape, bent and push fit into the diffuser before being reconnected with bare copper connections. This is the type of LED I used because its what I had already https://ae01.alicdn.com/kf/HTB19FOiNXXXXXcvaXXXq6xXFXXX8/High-quality-50x-12mm-DC5V-font-b-WS2801-b-font-Pixel-Node-Module-font-b-String.jpg it should also work with this type of WS2812 on round breakout boards http://tinkersphere.com/1450-thickbox_default/addressable-rgb-led-sequin-5v-ws2812-neopixel-compatible.jpg
The slot that the LEDs sit in is to be placed right behind the rear vertical tension member making it appear as if the light comes out 360degrees around the model.

These use a LOT of plastic. My entire print of 7 Constrictor diffusers and 1 Reactor diffuser used about 1/2kg of Natural PLA. Although this is a lot of plastic the effect it gives is an almost perfect column of light including the back side.

To print these you want to use a large layer height (0.3 or more) and a width of 0.5mm. You will only print a single perimeter, no infill and no top or bottom layers. If you have an option for spiral mode printing this would be the time to use it. You can also turn off retraction if your machine has a fast layer change to make it a single continuous perimeter without stopping. I used CA glue to connect the segments together. To do this is squirted a puddle of CA glue onto a piece of glass and then rubbed the ends in it before clamping the sections together. Once glued they were very strong and never came apart (make sure the ends are smooth).

NOTE: the Constrictor diffusers have a blank spot where there is no LED. This is the end that connects to the reaction chamber diffuser and in each additional section it will be behind the phase adjustment coils.

It uses the www.fastled.io library and runs on an Arduino Pro Mini clone and I communicate with it via an HC-06 bluetooth adapter. The Arduino and Bluetooth adapter are in the top injector cap and I have the power coming in the bottom injector cap.

I have included the Arduino sketch. Once running if you send it a ? over serial at the set baud rate it will reply with instructions on how to change the speed, color, saturation, brightness and pattern via serial. The sketch has define settings for how many LEDs and it should work with less sections and less LEDs but it has not been tested with less.

UPDATE: Feb 7, 2017
I updated the arduino sketch with missing data in serial help. I did not have instructions for the pattern settings in the serial help display.

https://theledroom.wordpress.com/2017/02/13/ncc-1701-d-warp-core/

The LED's have a direction. That is one side is IN and one OUT. The IN side I have at the top and OUT at the bottom. I have the power coming in the bottom (doesn't matter where its connected, it could be the middle or either end etc) and it's connected to the + and - terminals of the LED's.

I then connected the Arduino + and - to the + and - terminals at the top of the LED's. This now powers the Arduino. The last wires on the first (top) LED now connect to the Arduino (Data pin to pin 3 and clock pin to pin 9).

NOTE: The clock pin will not be used if using WS2812's and you will also need to comment out the clock pin in the sketch and change the line where is says " FastLED.addLeds<WS2801,DATA_PIN, CLOCK_PIN, RGB>(LEDarray,NUM_LEDS); " to say " FastLED.addLeds<WS2812,DATA_PIN, RGB>(LEDarray,NUM_LEDS); "

Once it's programmed and up and running you will be able to connect the bluetooth adapter to the Arduino. + to +, - to -, tx to rx, and rx to tx. You can not have the bluetooth connected to the Arduino while you program the Arduino because it uses the same serial port on the Arduino. There is a way to program over bluetooth but I haven't ever done it.

NOTE 2: Not all HC-05 and HC-06 modules can handle 5v signals from the Arduino and may require a couple of resistors to make a voltage divider for the Bluetooth rx line. See the tutorials below for more info and how to make one if needed. My unit had them built in so I was lucky.

Here are a few good references and tutorials about bluetooth modules with Arduino:
https://arduino-info.wikispaces.com/BlueTooth-HC05-HC06-Modules-How-To
http://www.instructables.com/id/AT-command-mode-of-HC-05-Bluetooth-module/?ALLSTEPS
https://www.hackster.io/mansurkamsur/upload-sketch-arduino-over-bluetooth-using-android-f1ce55
https://sites.google.com/site/wayneholder/inexpensively-program-your-arduino-via-bluetooth

comments.text: You are correct it does use a lot of plastic but I do not find it dims it too much. I run mine at around 20 out of 255 for the brightness because it is soooo bright especially at night. I would run it even lower but it makes the animations choppy. But if you are finding that you do not want to use it you could do something similar to the original by theplanetmike which is just a holder for the leds. It does not diffuse them at all so you would need wide angle LEDs. The reason I made the diffusers was to take the narrow 20degree beam from the LEDs and turn it into a column of evenly distributed light 360degrees around. This may be why you are feeling they are eating a lot of light because it is spread over such a large area. Either way the outer lens will diffuse whatever you put inside to some degree so I would just say experiment. Maybe having the LEDs facing backwards and bouncing off the back would work. Or you could put a strip inside a piece of polypropylene tubing just larger than the LEDs. Other types of white plastic tubing may work too.

comments.text: It sounds to me that there may be a wiring issue. To check you could upload one of the fastled example programs (you will have to change the LED type and pins in the example sketch). comments.text: Hard to say. If you shorted + to DI or DI you could have damaged the LED but I would look for wiring issues before LED issues. If you had shorted DI or DO to + you would most likely damage more than one LED. To prevent shorts you can use a small amount of Hot Glue or Nail Polish to insulate the bare wires but be warned that repairing things after gets much harder.

comments.text: Once you are feeling up to it I would add flux to all those joints and then remelt the solder with a hot clean soldering iron. This should reflow the joint and make sure it is working. You can have a joint that looks connected but doesn't work and adding flux and reflowing will make sure it is not that. I can not stress enough to use flux, good solder and a clean iron for all soldering. The best technician can't do anything with a dirty surface and/or bad solder.

title: M4 Magazine Adapter For M56 Airsoft Shotgun

description.text: Made a M4 magazine adapter for a DE M56 multi-shot airsoft shotgun. Pint as is with supports enabled. Support structure is probably going to be in the feed tube, there wasn't a way to get around that. Clean the feed tube with a string, wire or a screwdriver to clean the support structure out. There are two files, the first is the adapter and the second is the part that stops the loading door from moving. When first inserting the adapter it might not go in easily, after fitting it in a couple of times it should get easier. There will be support structure under the release lever, be careful and cut it with a hobby knife or utility knife. Do not insert a magazine until you have broken the release lever free from the support structure. Cut a pen spring in half for the release lever, it's not easy to fit it into the space behind the release lever. Uploaded a new mag adapter design to deal with feeding issues along with breaking after a couple of uses.

description.text: Made a mount clip for a airsoft M56A shotgun, the original one was too small for my two point sling. Print flat on the build surface, no supports needed. Remove the rubber back and remove the long screw all the way, slide out the old one the insert the new one. Reinsert the screw and fit the rubber part back over the end.

I saw someone post a pic of this idea, and I made my own version specific to the DeWalt 12" Trigger Clamp (medium). This is similar to the idea by Dasflux. See his design for less expensive alternative on the clamp end.

UPDATE: Added a version with no blades. Make with ABS or PETG for hard plastic claws.

The Thingi by Dasflux
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2056365

Here's a link to the clamp I used: http://www.homedepot.com/p/DEWALT-12-in-Medium-Trigger-Clamp-DWHT83140/204389260
Here's a link to the blades I used: http://www.homedepot.com/p/DEWALT-Drywall-Blade-5-Pack-DWHT11133/205400734

I peeled off the rubber guard on the clamp and replaced with my printed add-ons. Seat the blades in the printed piece first, then slide on to the clamp. I also used a few layers of blue painters tape on the face of the clamp to make the printed part slide on and stay by friction. (see pics)

Again, not my idea, but this is a print fitted specifically to the 12" DeWalt medium trigger clamp. It might fit the other medium claps, too.

title: Shake Table for Engineer's Week Project

description.text:
Mark III upgrade 1/26/18.
This upgrade takes out weak point in drive shaft to crank connection; adds a second crank to oscillate a parallelogram arm on the opposite side directly rather that through the table; and adds rotating lock pins to hold the platen in place without the need for binder clips. Consequently as the assembly of the drive shaft has got a bit more complex, I have added an exploded diagram to explain the layout.

The application: Students build towers from spaghetti and marshmallows then see if they can take the seismic forces from this little table. Upper table oscillates on 4 parallelogram arms, two of which are driven by a cranks. Cranks in turn are attached to a drive shaft with a 1/4" hexagon allowing it to be rotated by an electric screwdriver or cordless drill.

You will probably have to run a 1/4" drill through most of the holes to open them up for the pivot pins. Carefully squeeze the locking pins into the pivot pins using a "C" clamp. No glue is required. You will also have to use a small "Swiss" file to clean out the female drive on each of the cranks.

You need the follow # of items of each:

Baseplate New x 1
Top Plate x 1
Drive Shaft V4 x 1
Primary Crank x 1
Crank x 1
Shaft Lock x 1 - holds drive shaft in place, preventing axial movement, once fully assembled
Pivot Pin x 9 - two on each parallelogram arm; and one between middle of one parallelogram arm and drive arm
Long Pin x 1- same function as Pivot Pin but for the connection between Inner Drive Arm and middle of one parallelogram arms
Locking pin x 11 - two on each parallelogram arm; one between middle of one parallelogram arm and drive arm; one between middle of one parallelogram arm and Inner Drive Arm and one to lock the crank to drive arm
Parallelogram Arm x 4
Drive Arm x 1
Inner Drive Arm x 1
Lock Tab x 4 - to locate platen on top plate
Platen as required - suggest # of students /6 - this allows towers to be built off the shake table and loaded on for testing

I also downloaded the monkey at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1185699/#files to add to the fun - the kids have to make a tower that keeps the monkey from falling off it when shaken.

Video of demonstration at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=szCDBG8XrE0&spfreload=10

This project demonstrates how to use OpenSCAD to create 3D models with text labels that wrap around a corner. While OpenSCAD does not currently support obtaining the width of a label via font metrics (common to Java and other programming languages), the text width and height are constrainable via the resize() module.

See the project guide for more information including source code links, code walk through, and more.

http://onebeartoe.org/tours/3d-modeling/openscad/basics/text/around-the-corner-text/

https://plus.google.com/u/0/104101484714566033177
https://twitter.com/onebeartoe
https://www.youtube.com/user/onebeartoe/videos

I was inspired by several filament holder's on Thingiverse. I tried PHIL (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:996398), but I wanted a complete tray and I wanted the rollers a little farther apart and bigger diameter.

So I came across @pcdangio's Universal Filament Holder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1185076) that uses wide rollers so you can set a bunch of different width rolls on it. But, I wanted to have a lot smaller part list so that assembly was faster and use fewer fasteners. So I designed YASS.

I went for a version that uses all 3D printed parts, so I used @emmet's excellent gear bearing (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:53451). However, the trade-off is that to get a good bearing for the roller size, I ended up with a pretty small axle which will probably break. It'll be easy enough to replace the plastic pins with M4 screws.

Also, the model is parametric in Fusion 360 so it would be pretty easy to produce a roller.stl that is for a 624 bearing or some such.

The Fusion 360 model source is here: http://a360.co/2kMUN0p. Open it up in Fusion 360 and choose Modify->Change Parameters.

The 17tol version of the gear bearing is generated with a 0.17mm tolerance rather than the default 0.15mm tolerance that the other stl is at. It was easier to get a gear bearing that spun on my machine with the 20 microns of extra space (I think mostly because of too much squish on the first layer).

I put a little bit of Super Lube synthetic grease in the gear bearings, spun them a bit to work the grease in before inserting into the ends of the roller.
